Compiled by Shi Huijiao, a monk of Jiaxiang Temple in Kuaiji during the Liang Dynasty
Sacrificing One's Life, Part 6
Shi Sengqun, Shi Sengqun, unknown place of origin.
Pure and poor, abiding by his principles, eating vegetarian food and reciting sutras.
Later, he moved to Mount Huo in Luojiang County and built a thatched hut.
The mountain is isolated in the ocean, with a stone basin several dozen feet in diameter and six or seven feet deep, always with clear water.
The elders passed down the legend that it was the dwelling place of the celestial immortals.
Qun drank the water and did not feel hungry, so he stopped eating.
Later, Tao Kui, the Prefect of Jin'an, heard about it and asked for it.
Qun sent the water to Kui, but it smelled as soon as it left the mountain. This happened three or four times.

Kui crossed the ocean himself. The weather was very clear, but when he reached the mountain, it was windy, rainy, and dark. He stayed for several days but could not get there in the end, so he sighed and said:
The ordinary people in the world are finally separated from the sages.
He sighed with regret and returned.
The huts and alms bowls were separated by a small stream, and he always used a wooden beam to cross it to fetch water.
Later, there was a duck with a broken wing that spread its wings across the beam and pecked at the group from below.
The group wanted to use his staff to push it away, but feared it would be injured. Because of this, he returned and stopped drinking water, and died after several days, at the age of 140.
Before his death, he told people that when he was young, he had broken a duck's wing, and considered this to be his present retribution.
Shi Tancheng, Shi Tancheng, was a person from Hebei.
From a young age, he was kind and loving, and his kindness extended to insects.
At the end of the Jin dynasty, he arrived in Pengcheng and saw an old man, 80 years old, who was poor with his wife. He then gave up his precepts and became a slave, serving for many years.
But he cultivated morality within, never neglecting it, and the neighbors admired him.
The two old men, after their work, earned wages which they used entirely for the two old men's blessings.
He intended to redeem himself with it.
After the matter was finished, he wanted to return to the Way, but the Dharma requisites were not yet complete.
In the early years of the Song dynasty, there was a tiger disaster on the mountain below Pengcheng, and villagers were killed, one or two people per day.
Cheng then said to the villagers:
If the tiger eats me, the disaster will surely be eliminated.
The villagers bitterly remonstrated, but he would not listen. He then sat alone in the grass that night, and made a vow, saying:
With this body of mine, I will satisfy your hunger and thirst, and make you from now on cease your thoughts of enmity and harm, and in the future you will attain the unsurpassed Dharma food.
The villagers knew his intention was correct, and each wept and bowed before returning.

At the fourth watch, they heard the tiger take Cheng. The villagers chased it to South Mountain, where it had eaten his body completely, leaving only his head. They then buried him and built a stupa. After that, the tiger disaster finally ceased.
3 Shi Fajin Shi Fajin, also called Daojin or Faying, had the surname Tang and was from Zhangye, Liangzhou.
From a young age, he was diligent and austere, and his recitation was outstanding. He was respected by Juqu Mengxun.
When Mengxun died, his son Jinghuan was defeated by the Hu army. He asked Fajin:
Now I want to attack Gaochang, can I conquer it?
Fajin said:
It will certainly be a victory, but I worry about disasters and famine.
The army returned and immediately stabilized.
Three years later, Jinghuan died, and his younger brother Anzhou succeeded him.
That year there was a famine, and countless people died.
Since Anzhou served Fajin, Fajin often asked for help to relieve the poor and hungry.
The national reserves gradually became depleted, and Fajin stopped asking for help.
He then bathed and purified himself, took a knife and salt, and went to the place where the starving people gathered in the deepest poverty, and in order gave them the three refuges.
He then hung up his robe and bowl on a tree, and threw himself in front of the starving people, saying:
I will give you my flesh to eat together.
Although the people were hungry and exhausted, they still could not bear to accept it out of righteousness.
He then cut his own flesh, mixed it with salt, and ate it.
When the flesh of both thighs was exhausted, he fainted and could not cut it himself. He then told the starving people:
You can take my skin and flesh, which will be enough for several days. If the king's men come, they will surely take you away. Just take it and hide it.
The starving people grieved and no one could take it.
Soon his disciples arrived, and the king's men looked again.
The whole country rushed to the scene, crying and wailing.
He was then carried back to the palace.
The king ordered three hundred bushels of wheat to be given to the starving people, and separately released grain from the granaries to relieve the poor people.
He passed away the next morning, and was cremated to the north of the city.
The smoke and flames reached the heavens, and it subsided only after seven days.
The body was completely burned, but only the tongue did not rot.
A stupa with three layers was built at that place, and a stele was erected on the right.
The disciple Seng Zun, whose surname was Zhao, was a person from Gaochang.

He was good at the Ten Recitations Vinaya, ate vegetarian food, practiced asceticism, recited the Lotus Sutra, Suvará¹‡aprabhÄsa-sÅ«tra, and Diamond PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ-sÅ«tra, and was also diligent in teaching his disciples, always taking repentance as his practice.
Shi Sengfu, whose surname was Shan, was a person from Gao Yang.
His father Ba was the magistrate of Lan Tian.
Sengfu was orphaned at an early age and lived in poverty, but he was diligent in learning without satiation. He used firewood to make candles to illuminate his reading.
By the time he came of age, he had mastered all the classics and histories.
He had a handsome appearance and was good at conversation.
Later, he met Yang Yong, the General of the Wei Dynasty of the Later Qin, who provided him with clothing and food, and Xu Ziche took him along to study together.
When he listened to Master An's lecture on the Pan Gu Jing, he then had a mind to enjoy the Way. He thus shaved his head and followed Master An to receive the precepts.
After An's death, he returned to Tingwei Temple in Wei County, lowered his curtains, and secluded himself in contemplation, cutting off all worldly affairs.
At that time, there was a robbery in the village, and the robbers captured a young child, intending to take his heart and liver to appease the spirits.
Fu met the robbers at the entrance of the road to Xiaoyao, and upon learning their intention, he took off his clothes to exchange for the child, but the group of robbers refused.
Fu said:
Can the five internal organs of an adult be used?
The robbers thought Fu was not willing to give up his life, and his words were false.
Fu then thought:
My illusory and feverish body will die anyway. Using my death to save others, even in death it is as if I am alive.
He then took the robber's knife, cut open his chest to the navel. The group of robbers reproached each other, fled in all directions, and sent the child back home.
At the entrance of the road, a passerby saw Fu like this and asked him the reason. Although Fu was in a daze, he could still speak and fully answered with the story.
This man, grieving and heartbroken, returned home to get a needle and sewed up his abdomen, applying medicine to the wound.
He was carried back to the temple to rest, and in a short time he recovered.
Later, nothing is known of his end.
Shi Fa Yu, a monk from Jizhou.
He left home at fifteen and became a disciple of Hui Shi.
Shi established himself with a life of austerity and practiced the dhuta practices.
Yu was resolute and deeply understood the Way.
He always wanted to emulate Bhaisajya-rÄja and burn his body as an offering.
At that time, Yao Xu, the king of the pseudo Jin dynasty, was stationed at Puban. Yu told Xu about his plan. Xu said:
There are many ways to enter the Way. Why must you burn your body? I dare not strongly oppose you, but I hope you will think about it three times.
Yu's determination was heavy. He immediately ingested fragrant sawdust, wrapped his body with cloth, recited the Chapter on Abandoning the Body to the end, and set himself on fire.
Monks and laypeople watched, all feeling grief and longing.
At that time, he was forty-five years old.
Shi Huishao, unknown clan.
When he was a young child, his mother would feed him fish and meat, but he would spit it out. He would swallow vegetables without question.
Thus, he became a vegetarian.
At the age of eight, he left home to become a disciple of Sengyao.
He was diligent and persevering, and his ascetic practices were exemplary.
Later, he followed Yao to live at Zhaoti Temple in Linchuan. He then secretly had the intention to burn his body.
He always hired people to cut firewood and pile it up in a stone chamber on East Mountain, several zhang high. In the center, he opened a niche large enough to accommodate his body.
He then returned to the temple to take leave of Yao. Yao earnestly remonstrated with him, but he would not listen.
On the day of burning his body, he held a large assembly of eight precepts on East Mountain, and also took leave of his acquaintances.
On that day, the entire prefecture rushed to the waves. The number of carriages, horses, people, and those who brought gold and treasures was innumerable.

At the beginning of the night, he practiced the path, offered incense himself, and after offering incense, held a candle, entered the pyre, and sat down, reciting the chapter on the past events of the Medicine King.
When the assembly did not see Shao, they realized he had already left. Before the worship was finished, they all went to the pyre.
The pyre was already burning, and the chanting voice had not stopped.
When the fire reached his forehead, he heard him shout single-mindedly, and after saying this, he suddenly passed away.
The great assembly all saw a star, as large as a dou, go straight down into the smoke, and in a moment it went up into the sky.
Those who saw it all said that the heavenly palace welcomed Shao.
After three days, the pyre was completely burned.
Shao said to his fellow students before his death:
Where I burn my body, a paulownia tree should grow. Do not cut it down.
Three days later, it indeed grew.
Shao burned his body in the twenty-eighth year of the Yuanjia era, at the age of twenty-eight.
Shaoshi Sengyao was also pure and prudent, with noble virtues, and passed away at the age of 160 in the temple.
Shi Sengyu, with the surname Zhou, was a person from Yuhang, Wuxing.
He left home at a young age and his studies were pure and simple.
In the 15th year of the Yuanjia era, he built a monastery together with his classmates Tanyuan, Huiguang, and others on the southern ridge of Mount Lu, named Zhaoyin.
Sengyu always thought that the three evil realms were formed by the body, and since the mind was about to be exhausted, the body should also be reduced.
How far away is the practice of Yaowang?
Thus, he repeatedly made vows and began to plan to burn his body.

On the 3rd day of the 6th month in the 2nd year of the Xiaojian era of the Song dynasty, he collected firewood to make a coffin, invited monks to set up a vegetarian feast, and bid farewell to the assembly.
On that day, the clouds and fog were dark and heavy, and the rain fell heavily.
Sengyu then vowed:
If my aspiration is to be fulfilled, the sky should clear up. If there is no response, it should rain heavily.
Let the four groups know that the divine response is not obscure.
After saying this, the clouds and sky became clear.

When the first night was over, he entered the firewood chamber, joined his palms, sat upright, and recited the Chapter on the Medicine King. When the flames reached him, he still held his palms together without letting go.
The monks and laypeople who knew about this rushed to the mountain, all bowing and paying homage, vowing to establish karmic connections.
They all saw purple qi rising into the sky, which dissipated after a long time.
At that time, he was forty-four years old.

After twenty-four days, a pair of paulownia trees grew in Yu's room, with luxuriant roots and branches, the same size, piercing the ground and growing straight up, eventually becoming a rare tree. Those who understood the principle thought it was the precious Å›Äla tree.
Yu's aspiration to attain nirvana was fulfilled, so this manifestation appeared, and he was called the Åšramaá¹‡a of the Twin Paulownias.
Zhang Bian of Wu Commandery, who served as the Prefect of Pingnan, personally witnessed this event and wrote a biography and eulogy for him.
The eulogy says:
The profound mechanism is vast, and the ultimate way is vast.
From birth to death, who considers it a wonderful treasure? (1)
Since ancient times, the Medicine King has had extraordinary transformations beyond compare.
In the past, I heard his teachings, and now I see this person. (2)
The outstanding Å›ramaá¹‡a, with a mind firm in wisdom and concentration,
Concentrates his spirit in purple qi, and leaves traces under the twin trees. (3)
His virtue is delightful, and his conduct is valuable.

Shi Huiyi, Shi Huiyi, was a person from Guangling. He left home at a young age and stayed in Shouchun with his master.
During the Xiaojian period of the Liu Song Dynasty, he came to the capital and stayed at Zhulin Temple.
He diligently practiced asceticism and vowed to burn his body. When the people heard about it, some slandered him while others praised him.
In the fourth year of the Daming era, he started to stop eating grains and only consumed hemp and wheat.
By the sixth year, wheat and other grains were also exhausted, and they only ate ghee and oil.
After some time, ghee and oil were also cut off, and they only took fragrant pills.
Although the four elements were weak, their spirit and appearance were clear and correct.

Emperor Xiaowu deeply respected and admired them, and asked about them with sincerity. He sent the Minister of Education and King of Jiangxia, Yigong, to the temple to admonish Huiyi, but Huiyi's determination remained unchanged.
On the eighth day of the fourth month in the seventh year of Daming, he was about to burn himself. He placed a cauldron and prepared oil on the south of Mount Zhong.
On that day, he rode a bullock cart pulled by people from the temple to the mountain.

Since the emperor is the foundation of the people and also the one who entrusts the Three Jewels, he tried to enter the palace. He reached Yunlong Gate but could not walk down. He asked someone to report:
The monk Huiyi is now giving up his body. He comes to the gate to take leave and deeply entrusts the Buddha Dharma.
The emperor heard this and changed his expression. He personally came out of Yunlong Gate.
When Seng Yi met the Emperor, he entrusted the Buddha Dharma to him once again. Then, he took his leave.
The Emperor also continued to come, and the kings, queens, monks, nuns, and laypeople filled the mountains and valleys, throwing off their clothes and jewels, which were countless.
Yi then entered the cauldron, sat on a small bed, wrapped himself in clothes, put on a long hat, had oil poured over him, and was about to be set on fire.
The Emperor ordered the Minister of State Affairs to go to the cauldron and persuade him, saying:
There are many ways to practice the Way, why must you lose your life? Please think thrice and take a different path.
Yi's lofty will was firm, and he had no regrets.
He then replied:
My insignificant life is not worthy of being kept.
If the Heavenly Heart and the Sage's Compassion cannot let me go, I wish to have twenty people ordained.ğŸ”½The decree immediately allowed it. Yi then took a candle in his own hand to light his hat.
When the hat was lit, he discarded the candle, put his palms together, and recited the Chapter on the Medicine King.
When the fire reached his eyebrows, his chanting was still clear, but when it reached his eyes, it became indistinct.
The noble and humble lamented in sorrow, their voices echoing in the valleys, all snapping their fingers and chanting the Buddha's name, their grief-stricken tears falling.
The fire lasted until dawn the next day, when the Emperor heard flutes and panpipes in the air, and an unusual fragrance filled the air.
The Emperor returned to the palace that day, and that night he dreamed of Huiyi shaking his staff and coming to him, again entrusting him with the Buddha's teachings.
The next day, the Emperor held a gathering and ordained people, instructing the host of the vegetarian feast to announce and explain in detail the auspicious signs.
The place where he burned his body was called Yaowang Temple, in reference to his past life.
Shi Sengqing, Shi Sengqing, whose surname was Chen, was a person from Anhan in Baxi.
His family had been followers of the Five Pecks of Rice teaching for generations.
Sengqing was enlightened from birth. At thirteen, he left home and stayed at Yixing Temple.

He diligently practiced pure conduct, vowing to see the Buddha. He first burned off three of his fingers, and later vowed to burn his body. He gradually stopped eating grains and only consumed fragrant oil.
On the eighth day of the second month in the third year of the Daming era, he burned his body in front of the VimalakÄ«rti image he had created to the west of Wudan Temple in the city of Shu.
Prefect Zhang Yue personally came to observe, and the monks and laypeople of the region gathered to watch.
Circling clouds formed, and sorrowful rain fell.
Suddenly, the sky cleared, and the weather became clear and pure. A creature like a dragon was seen rising into the sky from the pyre.
At that time, he was twenty-three years old. Pei Fangming, the Prefect of Tianshui,
collected the ashes and built a stupa.
Shi Faguang, Shi Faguang, a person from Longxi in Qinzhou, had faith from a young age.
At the age of twenty-nine, he finally became a monk and practiced asceticism.
He did not wear cotton or silk, and abstained from grains, only eating pine needles.

Later, he vowed to burn his body and took pine resin and drank oil for half a year. On the 20th day of the 10th month in the 5th year of Yongming in the Qi dynasty, he gathered firewood inside Jicheng Temple in Longxi and burned his body to fulfill his previous vow.
When the fire reached his eyes, his recitation was still audible.
When it reached his nose, he became unclear and suddenly passed away.
He was 41 years old.
At the end of the Yongming period, there was a monk named Fazun in Shifeng County who also burned his body as an offering.
The prefect Xiao Mian sent the monk Huishen to build a stupa for his ashes.
Shi Tanhong, a monk of the Shi family, was a man from Huanglong.
He practiced precepts from a young age and specialized in the Vinaya.ğŸ”½In the Yongchu period of the Song dynasty, he traveled south to Panyu and stayed at Taisi Temple.
Later, he went to Xianshan Temple in Jiaozhi.
He recited the Sutra of Immeasurable Life and the Guanjing, vowing to be reborn in the Pure Land.
In the second year of Xiaojian, he gathered firewood on the mountain, secretly went into the pile, and burned himself with fire.
His disciples chased after him, embraced him, and took him back, but half of his body had already rotted, and he slightly improved after a month.
Later, he held a gathering near the village, and the entire temple attended.
On this day, Hong again entered the valley to burn his body. The villagers chased after him, and his life was already over.
Then they added firewood to the fire, and the next day it was completely burned out.
On that day, the villagers all saw Hong's body, the color of gold, riding a golden deer, going west very quickly, without time for greetings.
The monks and laypeople then realized his spiritual strangeness, and together they collected his ashes and bones to build a stupa.
The discussion says:
The most precious thing for those with form is the body;
The most treasured thing for those with emotions and consciousness is life.
Therefore, eating fat and drinking blood, riding on the fat and wearing the light, they want to be happy and comfortable.
They ingest Polygonum multiflorum and swallow cinnabar, preventing birth and nurturing their nature, wishing for longevity.
As for splitting a single hair to benefit the world, they are stingy and do not do it;
As for piercing a single meal to continue the rest of their lives, they are miserly and do not give it.
This is their great fault.
There are those who have great knowledge and insight, who abandon themselves to support others.
They consider the three realms to be the dwelling of a long night, and realize the four forms of birth to be the realm of dreams and illusions.
The spirit escapes like flying feathers, while the physical body is stuck in the bottle of grains.
Therefore, from the crown of the head to the feet, they never think of it as important.
The country, city, wife, and children, they give away like grass and weeds.
What I am discussing now are such people.ğŸ”½The monk Qun regarded one duck as his heart, and died in the water.
The monk Fu only saved a child, and cut open his abdomen to save its life.
Fa Jin cut his flesh to feed others, and Tan Cheng fed himself to a disaster tiger. These are all about the way of universal salvation, forgetting oneself and benefiting others.
In the past, when the prince threw himself into the fire, his merit surpassed that of nine kalpas;
When he cut his flesh to trade for a bird, it shocked the three thousand worlds.
Indeed, such a person is truly extraordinary and lofty.
Next, from Fa Yu to Tan Hong, they all burned their bodies, abandoning their precious belongings.
Some prayed for peace in the Pure Land, while others wished to be born in the Tusita Heaven.
Therefore, two paulownia trees appeared in his room, and a pavilion manifested itself in the sky.
The auspicious signs were brilliant, appearing with the times.
However, the teachings of the sages are not the same, and the prohibitions are also different.
If it is a great expedient for the sake of beings, adapting to the times and acting, benefiting in myriad ways, it is not restricted by the teachings.
Therefore, the sutra says:
Being able to burn one's finger or toe is even better than giving away a country or city.
If it is an ordinary monk who has left the household life, he originally uses dignified conduct to attract people.
But now, if he destroys his physical form and ruins the appearance of a field of merit, there are gains and losses in discussing it.
The gain is in forgetting the body, the loss is in violating the precepts.
Therefore NÄgÃ¢rjuna said:
Newly practicing bodhisattvas cannot practice all the perfections at once.
Sometimes they fulfill giving but violate filial piety, like a prince offering himself to a tiger;
Sometimes they fulfill wisdom but violate kindness, like investigating and fasting for others.
This is all because their practice is not yet perfect, and there are still excesses and deficiencies.
Moreover, the Buddha said that the body has 80,000 kinds of parasites that share the same qi as humans.
When a person's life ends, the parasites also depart together.
Therefore, after an arhat dies, the Buddha allows their body to be burned.
But now, if they are burned before death, there may be a loss in the life of the parasites, according to some.
Some say that since an arhat can still enter the firelight, what is there to be strange about?
Those who say they enter the firelight have already given up their lives beforehand.
Using the power of spiritual wisdom, they then burn themselves.
However, even bodhisattvas on the stage of nature have not yet escaped the retribution of the physical body.
Sometimes they throw their bodies into a fire pit, sometimes they split their bones and give them to people.
One should know that the discussion of killing insects is the most thorough in the end.
The three poisons and four inversions are the roots of birth and death;
The seven factors of enlightenment and eightfold path are truly the essential path to nirvana.
How can it be necessary to burn and scorch the body in order to leave suffering?

If one's position is close to attaining patience and one humbly traces back to the same as ordinary people, sometimes one may give up one's body for the sake of beings. This is not something that can be discussed.
As for ordinary people, their discernment is not extensive. In the end, they do not know whether practicing the Way until the end of one's life is better than giving up one's life.
Some want to invite praise for a while, some want to spread their fame for myriad generations.
When facing the fire and approaching the firewood, regret and fear are mixed.
Since their words are already widespread, they are ashamed to change their resolve.
Thus, I reluctantly followed the practice, enduring myriad hardships in vain. If so, this is not what is meant.
Commentary:
If a person stands out with determination, gold and stone are not considered extraordinary.
Melting away what is valued, seeking the jeweled city.ğŸ”½The fragrant osmanthus lush, the purple hall floating lightly.
Soaring smoke and radiant colors, exuding auspiciousness and containing blessings.
Still praised for a thousand autumns, its fragrance transmitted for myriad generations.

Shi Faxang, Shi Faxang, with the surname Liang, was from an unknown place.

Shi Sengsheng, Shi Sengsheng, whose surname was Yuan, was from Pixian in Shu Commandery.
He left home at a young age and was known for his ascetic practices.
Song Feng and others in Chengdu invited him to be the abbot of Sanxian Temple.
Reciting the Lotus Sutra and practicing meditation.

His disciples followed his last instructions.
Shi Fazong, Shi Fazong, was a person from Linhai.

When he was young, he liked to hunt. Once in Shan, he encountered a pregnant doe and shot her, causing her to miscarry. The doe, with an arrow still stuck in her, still went to the ground to lick her cubs.
Fazong then repented and realized that the desire to live and love one's cubs is something all sentient beings have in common.
He then broke his bow and arrows, left home, and practiced the Way.
He always supported himself by begging for food, practiced the one-meal-a-day discipline, and practiced austerities at the six periods of the day to repent for his past sins.
He recited the Lotus Sutra and the Vimalakirti Sutra.
She often recited on the terrace, and the sound was heard from afar.
More than three thousand people of the nobility and commoners received the precepts from her, and she expanded the place where she lived to make it a nunnery.
She named it after the sutra she recited, calling it Lotus Sutra Terrace.
Later, Zong's whereabouts are unknown.
